case_name: M. Golodetz Company v. the respondents

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 493 of 1960 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 29, 1959, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 177 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 493 of 1960. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 29,1959, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 177 of 1958.

facts.text: Appellants are a firm carrying on business as importers in the name and style of M. Golodetz Company at 120, Wall Street, New York in the United States of America.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are a firm carrying on business as importers in the name and style of M. Golodetz Company at 120, Wall Street, New York in the United States of America.

facts.text: Respondents are a firm carrying on business, among others as exporters of manganese ore and their principal office of business is at Bentinck Street in the town of Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents are a firm carrying on business, among others as exporters of manganese ore and their principal office of business is at Bentinck Street in the town of Calcutta.

facts.text: By a contract in writing dated July 5, 1955 the respondents agreed to sell and the appellants agreed to buy 25,000 tons of manganese ore on the terms and conditions set out therein.

anchor.surface_text: By a contract in writing dated July 5, 1955 the respondents agreed to sell and the appellants agreed to buy 25,000 tons of manganese ore on the terms and conditions set out therein.

facts.text: The contract contained the following arbitration clause: Any dispute arising out of the contract is to be settled by arbitration in New York according to the rules of the American Arbitration Association.

anchor.surface_text: The contract contained the following arbitration clause Arbitration Any dispute arising out of the contract is to be settled by arbitration in New York according to the rules of the American Arbitration Association.

facts.text: Between September 1956 and August 1957 the respondents supplied 5478 tons of manganese ore.

anchor.surface_text: Between September 1956 and August 1957 the respondents supplied 5478 tons of manganese ore.

facts.text: Disputes arose between the parties about the liability of the respondents to ship the balance of the goods not delivered.

anchor.surface_text: Disputes having arisen between the parties about the liability of the respondents to ship the balance of the goods not delivered,

facts.text: Appellants referred the disputes on or about January 15, 1958 to the arbitration of the American Arbitration Association and claimed compensation on the plea that the respondents had unlawfully made default in shipping the balance of the goods agreed to be sold.

anchor.surface_text: the appellants referred them on or about January 15, 1958 to the arbitration of the American Arbitration Association and claimed compensation on the plea that the respondents had unlawfully made default in shipping the balance of the goods agreed to be sold.

facts.text: On February 2, 1958 the respondents commenced an action on the original side of the High Court of Calcutta, Suit No. 194 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On February 2, 1958 the respondents commenced an action on the original side of the High Court of Calcutta claiming a decree that the written contract dated July 5, 1955 be adjudged void...

facts.text: Respondents claimed in suit that the written contract dated July 5, 1955 be adjudged void and delivered up and cancelled, perpetual injunction restraining appellants from enforcing it, and declaration that it stands discharged.

anchor.surface_text: claiming a decree that the written contract dated July 5, 1955 be adjudged void and delivered up and cancelled, that a perpetual injunction be issued restraining the appellants, their servants and agents from taking steps in purported enforcement of the said contract...

facts.text: Respondents' case: appellants had accepted manganese ore shipped till August 1957 in full satisfaction of their liability and the contract was discharged.

anchor.surface_text: It was the case of the respondents that the appellants had accepted manganese ore shipped till August 1957 in full satisfaction of their liability and that the contract was discharged...

facts.text: In alternative, respondents pleaded that appellants had repudiated the contract or committed breaches thereof, making it discharged or voidable, and they had avoided it.

anchor.surface_text: In the alternative the respondents pleaded that the appellants had repudiated the contract or had committed breaches thereof and on that account also the contract stood discharged or had become void or voidable at their option...

facts.text: In further alternative, respondents pleaded that the contract had become impossible of further performance, stood frustrated or discharged, exempting them from further performance.

anchor.surface_text: In the further alternative they pleaded that the contract had become impossible of further performance and that the same stood frustrated or discharged and they were exempted from further performance thereof.

facts.text: Appellants petitioned the High Court of Calcutta for stay of proceedings in suit No. 194 of 1958 under s. 34 of the Arbitration Act 1940 and injunction restraining respondents from proceeding with the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants thereupon petitioned the High Court of Calcutta for an order that the proceedings in suit No. 194 of 1958 commenced by the respondents be stayed by an order under s. 34 of the Arbitration Act X of 1940...

facts.text: Ray J held that s. 34 applies to foreign arbitration, no sufficient reason for not staying the action, and granted stay.

anchor.surface_text: Ray, J, who heard the petition held that to the agreement to submit the disputes to arbitration to a foreign arbitral body s. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act, 1940, applied... and that there was no sufficient reason for not staying the action filed in breach...

facts.text: In Letters Patent Appeal, Calcutta High Court reversed Ray J's judgment and vacated the stay order, holding trial court failed to consider evidence in India, foreign exchange difficulties, etc.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal under the Letters Patent against the order, the High Court held that the Court of first instance had not exercised its discretion properly for it had failed to take into consideration certain important circumstances...

facts.text: High Court noted all evidence regarding contract and disputes was in India.

anchor.surface_text: viz. that all the evidence regarding the contract and the disputes was in India,

facts.text: High Court noted special difficulties in securing foreign exchange for producing evidence before foreign tribunal due to Government of India restrictions.

anchor.surface_text: that there were on account of the restrictions imposed by the Government of India special difficulties in securing foreign exchange for producing evidence before a foreign arbitration tribunal,

facts.text: Advocate General for appellants conceded entire matter governed by Indian laws, Indian Arbitration Act and Indian Contract Act.

anchor.surface_text: The learned judges also observed that it was conceded by the Advocate General appearing on behalf of the appellants that the entire matter would be governed by the Indian laws, the Indian Arbitration Act and the Indian Contract Act...

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal preferred with special leave against High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order, with special leave, this appeal is preferred.

facts.text: Appellants averred in stay petition that it was bona fide, filed at earliest opportunity, ready and willing for arbitration, no sufficient reason not to refer to arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in their petition for stay averred that the petition was bona fide, and was filed at the earliest possible opportunity, that the appellants were ready and willing to do all things necessary for the proper conduct of the arbitration proceeding...

facts.text: Respondents contended in counter-affidavit that entire evidence and witnesses in India, no part in New York.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents by their counter- affidavit contended that the entire evidence regarding the subject-matter of the suit and all the witnesses in connection therewith were in India and that no part of the evidence...

facts.text: Respondents contended proper law of contract is Indian law.

anchor.surface_text: They also submitted that the proper law applicable to the contract dated July 5, 1955 was the Indian law and that the Indian law of Contracts would govern the rights and obligations of the parties.

facts.text: Appellants did not challenge in counter-affidavit that all evidence was in India and none in New York.

anchor.surface_text: By their counter-affidavit the appellants did not challenge the assertion made by the respondents that all the evidence in connection with the dispute was in India and that no part of the evidence was in New York.

facts.text: Supreme Court held circumstances make out sufficient reason for not granting stay, upholding High Court.

anchor.surface_text: ...the facts established make out sufficient reason for not granting stay.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on December 12, 1962 by Shah J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. December 12. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH,J.-
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 29,1959, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 177 of 1958.
Against that order, with special leave, this appeal is preferred.

arguments.claim: s.34 applies even to foreign arbitration tribunals

anchor.surface_text: We will assume for the purpose of this appeal that s. 34 of the Arbitration Act, 1940 invests a Court in India with authority to stay a legal proceeding commenced by a party to an arbitration agreement against any other party thereto in respect of any matter agreed to be referred, even when the agreement is to submit it to a foreign arbitration tribunal.

arguments.qualifiers: assume for the purpose of this appeal

arguments.claim: Court normally stays suit unless sufficient reasons shown, to enforce sanctity of contract and prevent approbate and reprobate

anchor.surface_text: Where a party to an arbitration agreement commences an action for determination of a matter agreed to be referred under an arbitration agreement the Court normally favours stay of the action leaving the plaintiff to resort to the tribunal chosen by the parties for adjudication. ... for not to do so would be to allow a party to the contract to approbate and reprobate, and this consideration may be stronger in cases where there is an agreement to submit the dispute arising under the contract to a foreign arbitral tribunal.

arguments.claim: Respondents' pleas constitute sufficient reason under Arbitration Act: evidence in India unchallenged, forex restrictions lead to ex parte injustice

anchor.surface_text: The High Court addressed itself to the question, whether the pleas raised by the respondents constituted sufficient reason within the meaning of the Arbitration Act, and pointed out, and in our judgment it was right in so doing, that the statement made in the affidavit of the respondent had remained practically unchallenged, that all the evidence in the case relating to the disputes was in India and that was a strong ground for not exercising the discretion in favour of the appellants.

arguments.claim: Balance of inconvenience favors refusing stay despite some inconvenience to appellants

anchor.surface_text: Undoubtedly the appellants would be put to some inconvenience if they are required to defend the suit filed against them in India, but the High Court has considered the balance of inconvenience and the other circumstances and has come to the conclusion, and in our judgment that conclusion is right, that the facts established make out sufficient reason for not granting stay.

arguments.claim: High Court properly interfered as Ray J failed to consider relevant affidavits and circumstances

anchor.surface_text: It was urged by counsel for the appellants that the High Court for reasons which were not adequate interfered with the order which was within the discretion of the trial judge and on that account the order must be set aside. But the High Court has pointed out that Ray, J., did not give full, proper and adequate consideration to all the circumstances and failed to apply his mind to the relevant affidavits from which it emerged that all the evidence relating to the dispute was in India

arguments.claim: No concession made before High Court that Indian law governs the contract

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants say that nosuch concession was made before the High Court by the Advocate-General, and the observations made in the judgment were the result of some misconception. Counsel relies in support of this submission upon an affidavit sworn by one Surhid Mohan Sanyal constituted attorney of the appellants filed in this Court on the day on which special leave to appeal was granted.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not necessary to decide proper law

holdings.text: We will assume for the purpose of this appeal that s. 34 of the Arbitration Act, 1940 invests a Court in India with authority to stay a legal proceeding commenced by a party to an arbitration agreement against any other party thereto in respect of any matter agreed to be referred, even when the agreement is to submit it to a foreign arbitration tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: We will assume for the purpose of this appeal that s. 34 of the Arbitration Act, 1940 invests a Court in India with authority to stay a legal proceeding commenced by a party to an arbitration agreement against any other party thereto in

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumed arguendo without deciding the jurisdictional question to proceed with the appeal.

holdings.text: Where a party to an arbitration agreement commences an action for determination of a matter agreed to be referred under an arbitration agreement the Court normally favours stay of the action leaving the plaintiff to resort to the tribunal chosen by the parties for adjudication unless there are sufficient reasons.

anchor.surface_text: Where a party to an arbitration agreement commences an action for determination of a matter agreed to be referred under an arbitration agreement the Court normally favours stay of the action leaving the plaintiff to resort to the tribunal chosen by the parties for adjudication. The Court in such a case is unwilling to countenance, unless there are sufficient reasons, breach of the solemn obligation to seek resort to the tribunal selected by him, if the other party thereto still remains ready and willing to do all things necessary for the proper conduct of the arbitration This rule applies to arbitrations by tribunals, foreign as well as domestic.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court enforces sanctity of contracts and prevents approbation and reprobation by parties; applies to both domestic and foreign arbitrations.

holdings.text: This rule applies to arbitrations by tribunals, foreign as well as domestic.

anchor.surface_text: This rule applies to arbitrations by tribunals, foreign as well as domestic. The power enunciated by s. 34 of the Arbitration Act is inherent in the Court the Court insists, unless sufficient reason to the contrary is made out, upon compelling the parties to abide by the entire bargain, for not to do so would be to allow a party to the contract to approbate and reprobate, and this consideration may be stronger

holdings.reasoning_summary: Extends domestic stay principles to foreign arbitration agreements under s.34.

holdings.text: Whether the circumstances in a given case make out sufficient reasons for refusing to stay a suit is essentially a question of fact.

anchor.surface_text: It is for the Court, having regard to all the circumstances, to arrive at a conclusion whether sufficient reasons are made out for refusing to grant stay. Whether the circumstances in a given case make out sufficient reasons for refusing to stay a suit brought in breach of an arbitration agreement is essentially a question of fact.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretionary determination based on all circumstances, treated as factual.

holdings.text: The pleas raised by the respondents constituted sufficient reason within the meaning of the Arbitration Act for refusing to stay the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court addressed itself to the question, whether the pleas raised by the respondents constituted sufficient reason within the meaning of the Arbitration Act, and pointed out, and in our judgment it was right in so doing, that the statement made in the affidavit of the respondent had remained practically unchallenged, that all the evidence in the case relating to the disputes was in India and that was a strong ground for not exercising the discretion in favour of the appellants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence location in India unchallenged; forex restrictions prevent participation, risking ex parte injustice.

holdings.text: The facts established make out sufficient reason for not granting stay.

anchor.surface_text: Undoubtedly the appellants would be put to some inconvenience if they are required to defend the suit filed against them in India, but the High Court has considered the balance of inconvenience and the other circumstances and has come to the conclusion, and in our judgment that conclusion is right, that the facts established make out sufficient reason for not granting stay.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balance of inconvenience weighs against stay despite some hardship to appellants.

holdings.text: The High Court properly interfered with the trial judge's order granting stay as he failed to consider relevant circumstances and affidavits.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged by counsel for the appellants that the High Court for reasons which were not adequate interfered with the order which was within the discretion of the trial judge and on that account the order must be set aside. But the High Court has pointed out that Ray, J., did not give full, proper and adequate consideration to all the circumstances and failed to apply his mind to the relevant affidavits from which it emerged that all the evidence relating to the dispute was in India

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial judge did not adequately consider evidence location and forex issues; appellate review justified.

holdings.text: It is advisable not to express any opinion on the question as to the law applicable to the contract.

anchor.surface_text: The two Courts below have differed on the question as to the law applicable to the contract... But on the view expressed by us, we deem it advisable not to express any opinion on the question as to the law applicable to the contract. It will be for the Court trying the suit to deal with that question, and to decide the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue left undecided for trial court; not necessary for this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Undoubtedly the appellants would be put to some inconvenience if they are required to defend the suit filed against them in India, but the High Court has considered the balance of inconvenience and the other circumstances and has come to the conclusion, and in our judgment that conclusion is right, that the facts established make out sufficient reason

outcome.relief_summary: High Court's order refusing stay of suit upheld; sufficient reason found for not staying the suit due to all evidence being in India and difficulties for respondents in foreign arbitration
directions: It will be for the Court trying the suit to deal with the question as to the law applicable to the contract, and to decide the suit.

anchor.surface_text: We will assume for the purpose of this appeal that s. 34 of the Arbitration Act, 1940 invests a Court in India with authority to stay a legal proceeding commenced by a party to an arbitration agreement against any other party thereto in

anchor.surface_text: Where a party to an arbitration agreement commences an action for determination of a matter agreed to be referred under an arbitration agreement the Court normally favours stay of the action leaving the plaintiff to resort to the tribunal chosen by the parties for adjudication. The Court in such a case is unwilling to countenance, unless there are sufficient reasons, breach of the solemn obligation to seek resort to the tribunal selected by him, if the other party thereto still remains ready and willing to do all things necessary for the proper conduct of the arbitration This rule applies to arbitrations by tribunals, foreign as well as domestic.

Undoubtedly the appellants would be put to some inconvenience if they are required to defend the suit filed against them in India, but the High Court has considered the balance of inconvenience and the other circumstances and has come to the conclusion, and in our judgment that conclusion is right, that the facts established make out sufficient reason

anchor.surface_text: It is for the Court, having regard to all the circumstances, to arrive at a conclusion whether sufficient reasons are made out for refusing to grant stay. Whether the circumstances in a given case make out sufficient reasons for refusing to stay a suit brought in breach of an arbitration agreement is essentially a question of fact.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court addressed itself to the question, whether the pleas raised by the respondents constituted sufficient reason within the meaning of the Arbitration Act, and pointed out, and in our judgment it was right in so doing, that the statement made in the affidavit of the respondent had remained practically unchallenged, that all the evidence in the case relating to the disputes was in India and that was a strong ground for not exercising the discretion in favour of the appellants.

Undoubtedly the appellants would be put to some inconvenience if they are required to defend the suit filed against them in India, but the High Court has considered the balance of inconvenience and the other circumstances and has come to the conclusion, and in our judgment that conclusion is right, that the facts established make out sufficient reason

Undoubtedly the appellants would be put to some inconvenience if they are required to defend the suit filed against them in India, but the High Court has considered the balance of inconvenience and the other circumstances and has come to the conclusion, and in our judgment that conclusion is right, that the facts established make out sufficient reason for not granting stay.

Undoubtedly the appellants would be put to some inconvenience if they are required to defend the suit filed against them in India, but the High Court has considered the balance of inconvenience and the other circumstances and has come to the conclusion, and in our judgment that conclusion is right, that the facts established make out sufficient reason

anchor.surface_text: It was urged by counsel for the appellants that the High Court for reasons which were not adequate interfered with the order which was within the discretion of the trial judge and on that account the order must be set aside. But the High Court has pointed out that Ray, J., did not give full, proper and adequate consideration to all the circumstances and failed to apply his mind to the relevant affidavits from which it emerged that all the evidence relating to the dispute was in India
